item.description:
Welcome! I am a PhD candidate in Political Science at the University of Pittsburgh. In Spring 2020, I will be a Visiting Researcher at Georgetown University’s Center for Latin American Studies.

My research interests are broadly in international and comparative political economy and political behavior.

My dissertation analyzes how public support for free trade evolves over time and the conditions under which policymakers adjust trade policy to voters’ preferences in developing democracies. My research agenda also includes work on the political economy of sovereign debt, international financial institutions, and intergovernmental transfers.

I am from Argentina, where I lectured in political science and international relations, mentored undergraduate students, and served as an economic policy analyst in Congress and the City Government of Buenos Aires.
